The Secretary of State for India informed theCabinet that he had recently made to Sir John Simona suggestion that the Indian Statutory Commission,now in India, should interview those interestsopposed to the boycott. This suggestion had been followed, and Lord Birkenhead read to the Cabinetthe telegram from Sir John Simon reporting theresult (circulated in Paper CaP.-45 (28)). on receipt of Sir John Simon's telegram Lord Birkenheadstated that he had seer Mr Ramsay MacDonald, whohad acceded to a suggestion by Sir John Simonand had sent a telegram to Mr- Hartshorn repudiatingthe authenticity of the news which had reached him from India that a claim was being made in india that if the obstruction were to succeed the IndianStatutory Commission would have to return homeand would be replaced by a new Commission, andthat in any -vent the Labour Party, if they came into power, would recall the Commission.-1- DEATH OP THE 2. The Cabinet bad before there a Memorandum(Paper C.P.-41 (28)) by the Secretary of Statefor Scotland, as Chairman of the Imperial wireless and Cable Conference, reporting the results ofthe Conference up to date, stating, that theDominions representatives are generally averseto amalgamation of the cable and wireless interests concerned in any form, but are unwilling to applyto their respective Governments for definite instructions on policy "until they have had a leadfrom the Imperial Government, and submitting thefollowing questions to the Cabinet:-Is the Cabinet prepared to agree Inprinciple to:(a) Handing over all Imperial com-munications - cable, beamwireless and beam telephone(when the latter arrives) tobe worked by(l) An amalgamated Marconi/BasternCompany, subject to appeal asto rates to some Tribunal,the Government having noholding in such Company.(2) A- Company in which His Majesty'3Government and the Dominionshave a controlling financial interest, the balance ofcapital being found by anAmalgamated Marconi/EasternCompany?If not,(b) The amalgamation of the Marconiand Eastern Companies to work theImperial and Foreign services atpresent conducted by them with aconcordat between such company and the Government as to theworking of their services andthe Government services? The Secretary of State for Scotland madeto the Cabinet a statement of the position, inthe course of which he referred to an investiga-tion he had carried out on the previous day intothe merits of new devices for securing secrecyfor messages sent by wireless telegraphy. Theresult had convinced him that secrecy was pro-bably in sight within the next few years throughthe use of certain machines, but it could not bedepended on at the present moment. Some expendi-ture would be required to bring the plan into full operation. Among other matters, Sir JohnGilmour mentioned the possibility that if thenegotiations between the Cable and WirelessCompanies were not successful, and no action were taken by the Government, there was a serious risk that all the cables might be bought by foreignHaving regard to the complexity of thequestion, the Cabinet agreed That a Cabinet Committee, composed as follows The Secretary of State for Scotland(In the Chair),The Home Secretary,The Secretary of State forDominion: A ffairs .The Secretary of State for War,The President of the Board of Trade,The Postmaster-General,The Financial Secretary to theTreasury, -should meet as soon as possible toconsider the questions raised in paper C.P.-41 (28) and should report their recommendations to the Cabinet. The Secretary of State for India informed the Cabinet that in regard to his Memorandumon the subject of the Indianisation of theIndian Army (Paper C.P.-29 (28)) he was in communication with the Secretary of State forWar, who had only just returned from India. he hoped to be in a position to put agreed proposals before the Cabinet at their Meeting next week.The Cabinet agreed That the question of the Indian-isation of the Indian Army shouldbe placed first on the Agenda fortheir regular Meeting in the following week. 5. The Gabinst had before them the following documents relating to Irish Loyalists:-A Memorandum (Paper CP .-38 (28))by the Lord Privy Seal, submittinga number of circumstances which,in his opinion, necessitated a re-consideration of the decision ofthe Cabinet last December, on thefollowing four grounds:-(i) That we cannot be less loyalto those who stood by us thana British Judge and an impartial Commission:(ii) That in certain cases thesuccessful applicants wereenabled to raise money upon their prospective awardswhich are now to be no awards:(iii) That from the amount recommendedno valid conclusion can be drawnthat because it is large thecase is one of less hardship;and, lastly,(iv) That the scale of reductionapplies to numbers of cases ofcompensation for injuriescognisable by the old Irish law,in regard to which we are abs o-lutely bound by the pledge of1922.A Note (Paper C.P.-40 (28)) by theChancellor of the Exchequer, circu-latins the terms of a communicationaddressed by the Secretary of Statefor Dominion Affairs on September 17,1926, to Sir Alexander Wood Renton.Referring to an allusion in his memorandum to certain cases where Banks had advanced moneyto Irish Loyalists on the strength of their claims,the Lord Privy Seal asked the Cabinet to note that credit had been given not on any assuranceor opinion from the Wood Renton Commission, buton that of a private organisation maintained bythe Claimants.After discussing the question in all its aspects, the Cabinet decided to reverse their previous decision (Cabinet 63 (27), conclusion is), and agreed - 1*1That the Chancellor of the exchequer should be authorised to make anannouncement (the terms of which hewould himself draw up) in the Houseof Commons to the general effect that,on the basis of the awards alreadyassessed by the Wood Renton Commis-sion, the Government have been ledto beljeve that a sum of one millionpounds will cover in full the totalclaims, including those remaining tobe assessed; but that they are unwilling to be committed tocontinued expenses in this connec-tion, or to surrender their responsi-bility in the matter; that, in thecircumstances, they propose to holdone million pounds as available forthese payments, and for the present-to pay a substantial percentage(to be fixed by the Chancellor ofthe Exchequer) of all claims alreadydealt with, the balance (if any) ofthe million pounds, after payment ofthe said percentage of all awards,,being held available for payment ofthe whole, or at any rate a part,of what is still outstanding tocomplete each payment. In this MemorandumMr Amery proposed to send a reply to the IrishFree State despatch, if possible on Wednesday,February 15th5 indicating general agreement inthe terms of the draft announcement proposed bythe Irish Fr^e State, and adding that we thinkit desirable also to make an announcement our-selves9 and that it is contemplated, therefore,on the assumption that an announcement will bemade in the Free State on Thursday, the 16th orpreferably Friday, the 17th February, to announce in Parliament here on Monday, the 20th, thatHis Majesty's Government in Great Britain were informed in advance of the announcement whichHis Majesty's Government in the Irish Free state proposed to make of the policy to be adopted inthis matter; that they indicated that they accept the view that it would not be equitablethat the transferred Civil Servants shouldreceive more favourable treatment In the matters in question than if they had remained in theCivil Service of this country9 and that theywould be prepared, subject to agreement as todetails of the legislation contemplated, to give their concurrence and co-operation In theproposed policy outlined by His majesty's government in the Irish Free State. The Cabinet bad before them a Memorandum(Paper C.P.-33 (28)) by the Minister of health in regard to the extension of the Local Authorities(Emergency Provisions) Act, 1926, in which he stated that he had come to the conclusion that theproper course is to put the control of theMetropolitan Common Poor Fund into the hands ofsome body representing the ratepayers of london as a whole, Including both those who paid to theFund more than they received and those whoreceived from the Fund more than they paid; andfurther suggesting that the appropriate body wouldbe the Metropolitan Asylums Board. Mr neville chamberlain therefore suggested that the extensionof the Act of 1926 should be accompanied by anew provision vesting, in the Metropolitan AsylumsBoard the control of payments out of the fund and the duty of protecting London as a wholefrom improper charges made by particular partsof London.After hearing a statement by the Ministerof Health, the Cabinet agreed To approve the proposals of theMinister of Health in Paper C.P.-33 (28) as summarised above.
